column1: 1	Swiss news via The Local	Allow porn in schools: Swiss men's group		9
column2: 212	36	Location: Zurich	16.07.2012
column3: 16:27	"    That's your words. What I said:

column1: - my lesson kick-off
- extreme example
- philosophy class
You mixed them all in your blender. Not me.
The reason I don't discuss the Local's lies is exactly what you point out: one does not discuss porn as such in class
column2: it's not a subject and not part of a subject either and won't ever be it. One knows that porn exist
column3: accepts this fact and does not censor it away from the actual teaching. We teach concepts
column4: and if by doing so
column5: we ""touch"" pornography
column6: then so be it. We don't avoid it here but it's not a porn class.

column1: Even in sexual education
column2: where the discussion about showing porn originated
column3: the idea is to liberate verbal expression in order to kill myths. Giving them condoms to roll up on colourful dildos is part of it
column4: the reflection leading to porn is the ground attitude that if one needs something in class
column5: we use it
column6: no censorship. How useful and for what pedagogical purpose porn could be useful
column7: that's the core of the discussion
column8: and it's not what TheLocal catching line is about. Hence my refusal to relate to them.

column1: By deviating to philosophy when talking about porn in this thread
column2: it should be clear that I don't advocate the use of porn films. Not because I'm shocked by it of even condemn it as such
column3: but only because in my professional eyes
column4: it would serve no pedagogical purpose. When porn is relevant to my teaching
column5: pictures are not necessary
column6: they all know what is it about and we can proceed to the actual teaching. But who am I to forbid other people to continue that discussion for sex education with pupils 16-19 years old? I do advocate sex education in school
column7: but I don't tell them how to do their job. There are enough people in the field of sex education who participate to this debate
column8: they don't need theLocal's headlines to lead a sensible pedagogical discussion.

column1: In each field of education
column2: there are outrageous ideas out there. Sex makes it to the headlines
column3: not the other ones. To me
column4: this story is a pedagogical discussion like another one. Business as usual
column5: people have different opinions
column6: exchanging ideas is always a good idea
column7: disagreeing is positive for constructive professional educational discussions etc.

column1: 7	Swiss news via The Local	Prosecutors arrest Swiss club Xamax's owner		31
column2: 121	8	Location: Zurich	27.01.2012

column1: Swiss football has quite a sophisticated youth development system coordinated by the national association. Xamax was at the time of their downfall responsible for one of the 13 top-level youth organisations in the country supported by the national association and covering the area of the cantons Neuchâtel and Fribourg.
When Xamax inc. went bankrupt
column2: the bankruptcy judge agreed to keep the youth organisation out of the bankruptcy estate
column3: so this part continued existing with the support of local Xamax-afficionados and the national association. The Under-21 team was at that time playing in 2.Liga Interregional becoming in the same year the 5th level with the introduction of the new national 3rd tier
column4: the Promotion League.

column1: So
column2: this Under-21 team is the basis of the new Xamax. The majority of the team are still today young players from their own youth organisation. But already from the beginning of the new Xamax some really good and experienced Challenge League (2nd tier)-players from the region (mostly Biel) could be added to the team.

column1: So
column2: Xamax moved up to the 1.Liga (4th level) in the first season and at the same time merged with the local FC Serrières already active in the 1.Liga (and rather a good team there). From a purely sport point of view the merger was not really necessary
column3: but they think it's better for sponsoring purposes to reduce local competition. So Xamax became again the nr.1 football club in the city after only one year.

column1: They managed also the promotion from 1.Liga the following year
column2: and currently
column3: Neuchâtel Xamax FCS is even in Promotion League on the first place after 17 out of 30 games with 4 points ahead of Rapperswil-Jona (the other team that moved up with them from 1.Liga this summer). Only the Promotion League champion is promoted at the end of the season to Challenge League.

column1: So
column2: they have good chances to move up to Challenge League. Afterwards
column3: it will be vital to not repeat the mistakes of the past. They had allowed for Chagaev to take over their club because their ambitions were too high-flying and not realistic in the first place.

column1: The situation has changed since their haydays in the 80-ies. Nowadays
column2: the place of a club like Xamax is between the lower half of Super League and the upper half of Challenge League. They have the potential to return to Super League
column3: but need to be aware that every now and then
column4: they can drop down to Challenge League and they need to refrain from unrealistic adventures trying to fool reality. FC Aarau is a good example for Xamax
column5: a club with very similar possibilites
column6: but more realistic expectations during the recent decade.

column1: We are (almost all I believe) foreigners. We (almost all) contribute to this country
column2: usually more than we get back. I don't mind that
column3: piece left for me is still generous enough for me to stay and having time of my life.

column1: These asylum seekers
column2: it's not an easy topic. Many sad stories. Problem is
column3: not many actually need protection. As said
column4: amounts to get here from Africa
column5: Asia are usually 5-digit USD equivalents
column6: and you need to be really rich there (or be utterly stupid and get to huge debt) to go for this ride.

column1: And Switzerland is tiny spec of dust. It cannot embrace all people from whole world (and Switzerland has quite a special status
column2: many people want to get exactly here
column3: not just generally Europe). So with current global economic conditions
column4: either flow is throttled quite intensively
column5: or problem gets worse.

column1: Mentioned Mongolians - I seriously doubt they are here for anything else than money. There are no persecutions of minorities there
column2: and the state is more or less democracy. So unless they are criminals back home
column3: this is economic migration. And same applies for many
column4: many others.

column1: If this would be up to me (and it is not
column2: correctly)
column3: I would accept only truly endangered people
column4: that can prove they would face execution or torture based on political/racial/ethnic membership. You know
column5: north korea
column6: few african states (really just few)
column7: and that's probably it. Rest of them
column10: but perfectly manageable (as they did before coming here).

column1: 176	Swiss news via The Local	Swiss-bashing hits new highs in EU: ambassador		4
column2: 893	22	Location: Zurich	04.06.2012

column1: I find it hard to believe that the Swiss government believed that there would be no response from the EU over their new immigration restrictions.  Certainly there will be intense pressure for a response within the EU from the nations who will suffer from the quotas
column2: and this is a core piece of EU ideology.

column1: When you have the economic upper-hand like the EU
column2: you can afford to impose ideological policy; in Switzerland's position
column3: you're left with the pragmatism of trying not to get your arm twisted too hard.

column1: As in all its dealings involving adopting EU regulations
column2: Switzerland has to make a decision as to the payoff between the cost of implementation versus keeping its major trading partner on favourable terms.  Economically
column3: Switzerland needs the EU more than vice versa
column4: so generally they are forced take the hit in return for the market access they need to survive - the potential cost of non-compliance is just too high.  Switzerland has to pick its fights carefully
column5: in those areas where it would otherwise have most to lose.

column1: However
column2: I'm not convinced Switzerland have picked their fight very well here - the imposition of the quota on this relatively insignificant group of people has relatively little to gain economically compared to what the EU could impose in revenge.  If they were talking about entirely rewriting their immigration relationship with the EU
column3: then it might have been a fight worth fighting - but at the moment
column4: the Swiss government are probably relieved that currently they are receiving only criticism and not action.

column2: 435	55	Location: Zurich	24.05.2012

column1: I really don't understand the negativity towards the EU (the Euro yes). Most (if not every) country in the EU has benefited from it in some way or another. Now I admit that not every country would but that I guess is a reason for not joining in the first place. Have to weigh the pro's and the cons.

There is a lot of negativity towards the Eu at the moment and that is normal with the catastrophe that the Euro has become. I acknowledge that some people have reservations about how it is run but that's par for the course with any large organisation.      If there is an opt out clause than it is not an obligation to EU membership and thus not mandatory. I'm sure the EU in general would prefer if the Euro was adopted but that's the beauty of democracy
column2: people make their own decisions.      I don't understand your point here in regards to the Lisbon Treaty. The people of the EU (or their elected representatives) ratified the Lisbon Treaty in all member states.      Would you care to expand on this and explain your reasoning. I'm honestly curious what it is about the EU that made it preferable to live elsewhere.      I don't know but who wouldn't want access to a market with 700 million people. I'm sure there are plenty of countries who would still love to join (and I guess will) once things settle down again. While I'm confident the EU (and the Euro) will survive
column3: what shape it's in by the end I'm guessing will be different than what it is now. Just my opinion however and I have nothing to back it up with.      The thing about democracy is that people can just keep saying no and then vote in another crowd during the next elections who don't ask the question. If they no longer ask however and just go ahead and do to it as you seem to be insinuating then indeed the EU has a major problem.

column1: What advantages are there for the Euro to fall apart for the countries who have adopted it. The Euro in principle is a great idea it's just the implementation which left a lot to be desired in my opinion.
In regards to the EU and dictating rather than negotiating I don't see the problem (well in general). The EU attempts to look after its own citizens and interests as a priority over others
column2: what country or similar organisations don't? To me it just makes sense.

column1: For the record (in case you haven't guessed by now  ) I'm very much pro EU however I don't say that everything the EU does is good. It has its flaws but its the job of it's citizens to try to rectify that just as in any other country.

column1: 249	Swiss news via The Local	Racism rife in Switzerland: human rights chief		15
column2: 700	280	Location: Zurich	29.03.2012
column3: 11:06	"    I would disgree with that.

column1: Switzerland has accepted its status as a multicultural and multilingual country at a much earlier point in history than any other country I can think of. It was until Mitterand came to power that the French government was awkwardly ignoring the very existence of such minority languages and cultures as Breton and Basque. In the UK Welsh did not start gaining any official recognition until about the 1980s and Scottish Gaelic still has no legal recognition today. As recently as post WW2
column2: ethic cleansings in Eastern Europe led to the expulsion of ethnic Germans from places like the Sudetenland and Poland. Even today
column3: Spain and Belgium are struggling to remain united countries due to groups that were oppressed in recent history distrusting the new staus quo and wanting their own countries (and who knows how long Scotland will remain part of the UK?). In comparison
column4: Switzerland has enjoyed a long period of comparative peace between the linguistic and cultural groups in the country. There have not always been sunflowers and rainbows but disputes were mostly solved in an amicable way. To say Switzerland doesn't get multiculturalism is misrepresting history in a big way.

column1: "	Posts: 1
column2: 154	Join Date: Mar 2011	Forum Veteran	Groaned at 107 Times in 52 Posts	Thanked 77 Times in 52 Posts	h

column1: 542	Swiss news via The Local	Petroplus to file for insolvency		501	1	Location: Zurich	24.01.2012

Inevitable really considering the business model and the huge debt they hold (1.75 billion $). Petroplus announced losses of $750 mm for nine months of '11 and there is little to be hopeful about as refining margins remain desperately low.
They have 5 European refineries that will need to find new operators or close:
Ingolstad: I think can operate profitably and should find a future.
Coryton; probably can too
Cressier: may be saved by its location and the Swiss gasoline needs
Antwerp and Petit Couronne are hopeless and unlikely to survive.       "	Posts: 1

column4: and when the place of work of the weapons-holder was less than 5 kilometers away from home. column5: and this without much ado and in many places (places less than 5 km away from home). The last proposal which was recjected did NOT include much help for the soldiers but mostly restrictions. Any new proposal also has to include the interests of the Shooting Associations which are very powerful outside the cities.
